input: error: 'x' was not declared in this scope
output:
🟥 Error Overview
Error Message: error: 'x' was not declared in this scope
Language / Tool: C/C++ Compiler

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 7
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)
The variable was used before being declared.

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
int main() {
    cout << x;
}

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
int main() {
    int x = 10;
    cout << x;
}

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Variables must be declared before use.

📝 One-Line Summary
The error occurred due to incorrect code structure and was fixed by correcting it.

input: error: 'cout' was not declared in this scope
output:
🟥 Error Overview
Error Message: error: 'cout' was not declared in this scope
Language / Tool: C/C++ Compiler

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 12
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)
The compiler does not recognize cout because it was not properly included.

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
int main() {
    cout << "Hello";
}

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;
int main() {
    cout << "Hello";
}

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Standard library features require proper headers.

📝 One-Line Summary
The error occurred due to incorrect code structure and was fixed by correcting it.

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 7
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
int main() {
    int x = 10
}

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
int main() {
    int x = 10;
}

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Every statement in C/C++ must end with a semicolon.

📝 One-Line Summary

input: error: too few arguments to function
output:
🟥 Error Overview
Error Message: error: too few arguments to function
Language / Tool: C/C++ Compiler

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 10
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)
The function was called without all the required arguments.

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
void add(int a, int b) {}
int main() {
    add(5);
}

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
void add(int a, int b) {}
int main() {
    add(5, 10);
}

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Functions must be called with the correct number of arguments.

📝 One-Line Summary
The error occurred due to incorrect code structure and was fixed by correcting it.

Error Message: error: array subscript is not an integer
Language / Tool: C/C++ Compiler

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 11
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)
Array indices must be integers.

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
int arr[5];
arr["one"] = 10;

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
int arr[5];
arr[1] = 10;

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Use only integer values to index arrays.

📝 One-Line Summary
The error occurred due to incorrect code structure and was fixed by correcting it.

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 9
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
int x = 5;
char* s = "hi";
int y = x + s;

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
int x = 5;
int y = x + 10;

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Binary operators require compatible data types.

The error occurred due to incorrect code structure and was fixed by correcting it.

📌 Rule to Remember
Pointers must store addresses, not values.

📍 Where the Error Occurs

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
int x = 5;
int x = 10;

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code

x = 10;

📌 Rule to Remember
A variable can only be declared once per scope.

📌 Rule to Remember

📍 Where the Error Occurs
File: main.cpp
Line: 10
Code Context: A statement is being processed by the compiler.

🧠 What the Error Means (Plain English)
The function was called without all the required arguments.

❓ Why This Error Happens
Cause 1: Incorrect syntax or usage

❌ Problematic Code
void add(int a, int b) {}
int main() {
    add(5);
}

Explanation: The code violates a C/C++ language rule.

✅ Corrected Code
void add(int a, int b) {}
int main() {
    add(5, 10);
}

Explanation: The code now follows correct syntax and rules.

📌 Rule to Remember
Functions must be called with the correct number of arguments.

📌 Rule to Remember
